events.event_description: Wind generation in the Midwest experienced significant curtailment, with grid operators restricting an average of 800 MW in 2023 compared to less than 200 MW in 2019.
events.citation: Grid operators in the areas overseen by the Southwest Power Pool (SPP) and Midcontinent Independent System Operator (MISO) curtailed an hourly average of 800 megawatts (MW) of wind generation in the Midwest last year, compared with less than 200 MW in 2019.

events.event_description: Wind generation in the Midwest increased by 42% between 2019 and 2023, leading to increased curtailment needs due to grid congestion and oversupply.
events.citation: Wind generation increased by 42% between 2019 and 2023 and makes up a substantial proportion of the energy mix in the Midwest.

events.event_description: During Winter Storm Heather, MISO set a wind generation record of nearly 26 GW within one hour while maintaining reduced curtailment levels.
events.citation: Although wind generation within MISO set a record of almost 26 gigawatts (GW) within one hour and averaged 16 GW per hour during Winter Storm Heather in January 2024, MISO curtailed wind generation 12% less throughout winter 2023–24 than in the previous winter

events.event_description: In 2022, MISO experienced extreme wind curtailment events reaching up to 5.9 GW in some hours due to transmission congestion.
events.citation: In MISO, the market monitor found that high wind output caused almost half of MISO's transmission system congestion in 2022, resulting in average hourly wind curtailments of 726 MW per hour, including curtailments of as much as 5.9 GW in some hours of 2022.
